prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: “Tag-along” actions are actions that apparently share common facts with other actions that have previously been transferred by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. Tag-along actions include those filed after the initial hearing on transfer and actions that were then pending but were not brought to the attention of the Panel.

The legal standards for transfer of tag-along actions are the same as those applying to initial transfer. The requirements of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 must be met in order for the Panel to order transfer of a tag-along action. The requirements of the statute are discussed in Chapter 5. The Panel looks at the litigation as a whole, including the actions previously transferred and still pending in the transferee court and the potential tag-along actions to determine if the statute is satisfied.

The Panel's treatment of tag-along actions has generally been to order transfer. Once the Panel has ordered transfer of a set of actions, transfer of additional actions is both logical and likely to advance the purposes of transfer. The Panel has stated that a “strong preference” exists favoring transfer since the transferee court is presumed to have set in place mechanisms for handling the cases and has gained familiarity with the issues. The Panel frequently points out that particular tag-along actions are suitable for transfer for the same reasons the docket initially was transferred.[1] The Panel has also made it clear, however, that the entry of a conditional transfer order transferring a case to the transferee court does not reflect a presumption that transfer will take place.[2]

Potential tag-along actions clearly enter into the Panel's calculus in determining whether to order transfer. A docket with few pending tag-along actions but many potential tag-along actions is treated as being bigger than the number actually before the Panel.[3] Similarly, the Panel has looked to potential tag-along actions as relevant to its selection of a transferee district.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
